document.title: Newton’s identities and the pentagonal number theorem

para.p: The pentagonal number theorem is the identity

Math.text: ((product _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(1 - x ^ n) = ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n * x ^ ((n * (3 * n - 1)) / 2))

In [], Euler uses Newton’s identities together with the pentagonal number theorem to prove identities for divergent series. Euler says that all the roots of unity of each power will be roots of the equation

and so if we denote the roots by
α , β , γ , δ
, etc. then
By applying Newton’s identities, Euler gets
and likewise formulas for the sums of the higher powers of the roots. Rademacher [] clarifies these statements.

Euler uses Newton’s identities in his discovery of the values of

. Generally, Euler uses Newton’s identities to relate expressions for the same thing as sums and products, such as the representations of Bessel functions as infinite series and infinite products (cf. [, pp. 497–503]).
